occurrences.line_text: His aged wife, with many others wide:
Ne stayeth leaue to take, before his friends doe dye.
His target alwayes ouer her pretended;
Yet holding fast twixt both his armes extended
And in his armes the dreary dying mayd,
And saw his shepheards cottage spoyled quight,
And his Loue reft away, he wexed wood,
That euen his hart for very fell despight,
And his owne flesh he readie was to teare:
That more increast the anguish of his paine.
And yet his feare did follow him behynd:
That he no word could speake, but smit his brest,
And vp to heauen his eyes fast streming threw.
Where was his Pastorell? where all the other crew?
Old Meliboe and his good wife withall
His hart quite deaded was with anguish great,
And all his wits with doole were nigh distraught,
That he his face, his head, his brest did beat,
That he his face, his head, his brest did beat,
That he his face, his head, his brest did beat,
But after griefe awhile had had his course,
Began to mitigate his swelling sourse,
And in his mind with better reason cast,
Then for to die with her, and his liues threed to breake.
To wend with him, and be his conduct trew
Right well knew Coridon his owne late sheepe,
His hart gan fayle, albe he saw them all asleepe.
But Calidore recomforting his griefe,
Though not his feare; for nought may feare disswade;
But he, that in his mind had closely made
Knowing his voice although not heard long sin,
He breath'd his sword, and rested him till day:
Through the dead carcases he made his way;
But he doth with his raging brond diuide
Disperseth them to catch his choysest pray;
That none his daunger daring to abide,
Fled from his wrath, and did themselues conuay
Then backe returning to his dearest deare,
Of which the best he did his loue betake;
Had reft from Meliboe, and from his make,
So droue them all away, and his loue with him bore.
This gentle knight, from sewing his first quest,
To his atchieuement of the Blatant beast;
Who whylome was in his youthes freshest flowre
For his great riches and his greater might.
For his great riches and his greater might.
Or secret guifts so with his keepers wrought,
That to his loue sometimes he came in place,
His fleecie flocke vpon the playnes around,
He tooke it vp, and in his mantle wound;
So home vnto his honest wife it bore,
And loued for his prowesse, sith they twaine
Of his first quest, which he had long forlore;
As through the world thereby should glorifie his name.
To leaue his Loue, now perill being past,
So taking leaue of his faire Pastorell,
He went forth on his quest, and did, that him befell.
But first, ere I doe his aduentures tell,
During his absence left in heauy care,
Acknowledg'd for his owne faire Pastorell.
Him follow'd, by the tract of his outragious spoile.
Knowing his fatall hand by former feare;
With his sharpe steele, and ran at him amaine
That terrifide his foes, and armed him,
At all, that came within his rauenings,
Or bit them with his banefull teeth of iniury.
That th'outrage of his violence he stayd,
And spitting forth the poyson of his spight,
That fomed all about his bloody iawes.
Tho rearing vp his former feete on hight,
He rampt vpon him with his rauenous pawes,
As if he would haue rent him with his cruell clawes.
But he right well aware, his rage to ward,
Did cast his shield atweene, and therewithall
Putting his puissaunce forth, pursu'd so hard,
His shield he on him threw, and fast downe held;
To crop his thousand heads, the which still new
Who nathemore his heauy load releast,
But aye the more he rag'd, the more his powre increast.
By force, he gan his hundred tongues apply,
At last when as he found his force to shrincke,
Therewith he mured vp his mouth along,
And therein shut vp his blasphemous tong,
With which he drew him forth, euen in his own despight.
Against his will fast bound in yron chaine,
So led this Knight his captyue with like conquest wonne.
But trembled vnderneath his mighty hand,
Reioyced much to see his captiue plight,
With his vile tongue, which many had defamed,
Or fault of men, he broke his yron chaine,
And all his brethren borne in Britaine land;
Hope to escape his venemous despite,
And idle pleasures in his[her] Bowre of Blisse,
For her he hated as the hissing snake,
Orion, flying fast from hissing snake,
That I may tell this haplesse history?
That all this famous antique history,
Whom antique history so high doth raise,
And therein all the famous history
As ye may elsewhere read that ruefull history.
So oft as I this history record,
A famous history to be enrold
Another arrow hath your louers hart to hit.
To saluage chace, where I thereon may hit
Hither (quoth he) me Archimago sent,
That hath thee hither brought to taste mine yre?
In euill houre thy foes thee hither sent,
Hath brought you hither into Faery land,
Me hither sent, for cause to me vnghest,
Me hither brought by wayes yet neuer found,
What grace hath thee now hither brought this way?
Or doen thy feeble feet vnweeting hither stray?
That hither turnes his steps. So few there bee,
O matrone sage (quoth she) I hither came,
And labours long, through which ye hither came,
Ye then shall hither backe returne againe,
The fond encheason, that me hither led.
Come hither, come hither, Ã´ come hastily;
Come hither, come hither, Ã´ come hastily;
(O hideous hunger of dominion) hither came.
Of Rome againe, who hither hastly sent
Hither came Ioseph of Arimathy,
Which when the Romanes heard, they hither sent
As did this knight, before ye hither came.
Or other mightie cause vs two did hither send.
Hath hither brought, for succour to appele;
Hither great Venus brought this infant faire,
Till thou cam'st hither to augment our mone,
What new ocasion doth thee hither driue,
In piteous languor, since ye hither came,
Hither those Brigants brought their present pray,
More ample spirit, then hitherto was wount,
It was in my mishaps, as hitherward
O turne thy rudder hither-ward a while:
And where he hits, nought knowes, & whom he hurts, nought cares.
After their hiues with honny do abound:
That creeping close, amongst the hiues to reare
By the hoare lockes, that hong before her eyes,
That the hoare waters from his frigot ran,
His feete all bare, his beard all hoarie gray,
And hoarie head of Archimago old,
As hoarie frost with spangles doth attire
The whiles that hoarie king, with all his traine,
Of ripest yeares, and haires all hoarie gray,
Her lockes, that loathly were and hoarie gray,
Whose hoarie locks great grauitie did crowne,
With hoarie lockes all loose, and visage grim;
With the brode shadow of an hoarie hill,
His face was rugged, and his hoarie hed
With rugged beard, and hoarie shagged heare,
And sad Asopus, comely with his hoarie head.
But the bare ground, with hoarie mosse bestrowed,
The hoars Night-rauen, trump of dolefull drere,
But yelling Meawes, with Seagulles hoarse and bace,
Where he hath left his plumes all hoary gray,
With head all hoary, and his beard all gray,
For many scarres and many hoary heares,
Is this the hope that to my hoary heare
Eftsoones they saw an hideous hoast arrayd,
In bloud of Kings, and great hoastes to subdew?
That had an hog beene late, hight Grille by name,
That had from hoggish forme him brought to naturall.
Let Grill be Grill, and haue his hoggish mind,
The westerne Hogh, besprincled with the gore
His grasping hold, and from her turne him backe:
I deeme your loue, and hold me to you bound;
The Fort, that Ladies hold in soueraigne dread.
But suddaine catching hold, did her dismay
Till Vna cride, O hold that heauie hand,
His hastie hand he doth amazed hold,
Who by her cleanly garment catching hold,
Vpon the scepter, which she now did hold:
With precious mettall full, as they might hold,
Whom great griefe made forget the raines to hold
In vaine he seekes that hauing cannot hold.
O hold thy mortall hand for Ladies sake,
Hold for my sake, and do him not to dye,
Remedilesse, for aie he doth him hold;
You to haue helpt I hold my selfe yet blest.
And in her other hand she fast did hold
And taught him how to take assured hold
Much was the man encombred with his hold,
Thrise happy man the knight himselfe did hold,
Sith heauen thee deignes to hold in liuing state,
Or hold sad life in long captiuitee:
Ne euer shall I rest in house nor hold,
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
And cleeped him his liege, to hold of him in fee.
That none thereof could euer taken hold,
His grasping hold: so lightly did vpstart,
And catching hold of her vngratious tong,
And of him catching hold him strongly stayd
What secret place (quoth he) can safely hold
He ouer him did hold his cruell clawes,
To catchen hold of that long chaine, thereby
On either side, that neither mayle could hold,
And in her hand a Poplar braunch did hold:
What wight she was, that Poplar braunch did hold:
Which they should hold of him, as subiect to Britayne.
And catching hold of him, as downe he lent,
Out of his hold, and broke his caitiue bands,
For all that here on earth we dreadfull hold,
As those vnruly beasts to hold without;
Which fled so fast, that nothing mote him hold,
And her knights seruice ought, to hold of her in fee.
And hold them backe, that would in errour fall;
Sithens it hath infixed faster hold
Enough to hold a foole in vaine delight:
Yet all that could not from affright her hold,
For sure a foole I do him firmely hold,
A mortall bow and arrowes keene did hold,
She alway smyld, and in her hand did hold
Shame burning brond-yrons in her hand did hold:
And vnawares vpon her laying hold,
Therefore this Fay I hold but fond and vaine,
Whether shall haue the Hag, or hold the Lady still.
Her hand fell downe, and would no longer hold
To whom his faith he firmely ment to hold,
Yet she him still detaines in captiue hold
From greedy hold of that his blouddy feast:
Might be my lucky lot; sith all by lot we hold.
Caught hold on me, and thought my steps to stay,
Were cowards knowne, and litle count did hold,
Vpon a recluse Virgin to lay hold,
For Cupids man with Venus mayd to hold,
And warlike people, which the Britaine Islands hold.
Can from all men so rich a kingdome hold;
One prison fittest is to hold vs two:
And on him catching hold, gan loud to crie
Else he doth hold him backe or beat away.
Eftsoones him selfe he from his hold vnbownd,
And catching hold of this Sea-beaten chest,
I hold mine owne, and so will hold it still.
I hold mine owne, and so will hold it still.
All the braue Knights, that hold of Maidenhead,
His mightie hands, the distaffe vile to hold,
Yet doubting least his hold was but vnsound,
That from thy tongue thy hearts intent doth hold.
Which late her folke had slaine, she bad the[m] forth to hold.
Nor hold from suite of his auowed quest,
Eftsoones they gan their wrothfull hands to hold,
Fit to catch hold of all that he could weld,
Warning him hold it fast, for feare of slights.
And on his shield tooke hold with all her might,
But dearer then the[m] both, your faith once plighted hold.
From his right course, but still the way did hold
(Quoth he) I hold it no indignity;
Of which occasion Aldine taking hold,
Tho on his shield he griple hold did lay,
He with him closd, and laying mightie hold
And quietly doth hold it in his hand,
But the steele-head no stedfast hold could fynd,
They downe him hold, and fast with cords do bynde,
And now haue prou'd, what happineesse ye hold
With that they hold: each hath his fortune in his brest.
In his strong hand their rugged teats to hold,
The rest take if they would, he her to him would hold.
Or how those theeues, whilest one sought her to hold,
Both staring fierce, and holding idely
Holding in hand a goodly arming sword,
Holding a staffe in hand for more formalitee.
All holding crosses in their hands on hye,
Holding a lattice still before his face,
Stood still amaz'd, holding his idle sweard;
Holding her hand vpon her gentle hart;
Still holding vp her suppliant hands on hye,
Vpon a rocke, and holding forth on hie
Holding a Scepter in her royall hand,
Crying, and holding vp her wretched hands
But holding vp his hands, with silence mercie prayd.
Yet holding fast twixt both his armes extended
That holds the world in his still chaunging state,
But that she holds them with her blessed hands.
By which he stil them holds, & keepes with strong effort.
But forth vnto the darksome hole he went,
To yawning gulfe of deepe Auernus hole.
By that same hole an entrance darke and bace
And downe them poured through an hole full wide,
Or that darke dreadfull hole of Tartare steepe,
Still as his wound did gather, and grow hole,
And perfect hole, prostrate she fell vnto the ground.
Till of his wounds he wexed hole and strong,
How to saue hole her hazarded estate;
That were all worme-eaten, and full of canker holes.
And hid themselues in holes and bushes from his vew.
That still it breathed forth sweet spirit & holesome smell.
More sweet and holesome, then the pleasaunt hill
With holesome reede of sad sobriety,
The Patron of true Holinesse,
to house of Holinesse,
Shall drowne all Holland with his excrement,
At length it brought them to a hollow caue,
With hollow howling, and lamenting cry,
Her hollow womb did secretly inspire,
The neighbour woods around with hollow murmur ring.
Therewith an hollow, dreary, murmuring voyce
His sad dull eyes deepe sunck in hollow pits,
With stony eyes, and hartlesse hollow hew,
His dwelling has, low in an hollow caue,
And hid his face; through which his hollow eyne
Were like two sayles, in which the hollow wynd
But farre within, as in a hollow glade,
That deepe emperst his darksome hollow maw,
Some lingring life within his hollow brest,
Into the hollow earth, them there to hide.
And in the hollow earth haue their eternall brood.
That deepe descended through the hollow ground,
Staring with hollow eyes, and stiffe vpstanding heares.
Bent hollow beetle browes, sharpe staring eyes,
Like as a fire, the which in hollow caue
The hollow vessell through the threatfull waue,
With dreadfull noise, and hollow rombling rore,
For thy it round and hollow shaped was,
Sorrow is heaped in thy hollow chest,
Certaine sad words, with hollow voice and bace,
It is an hideous hollow caue (they say)
And housed is within her hollow brest,
Out of their hollow bosome forth to throw
Is built of hollow billowes heaped hye,
There in a gloomy hollow glen she found
And with fell looke and hollow deadly gaze
Whose trampling feet vpon the hollow lay
Therein is eaten out an hollow caue,
Which in th'earthes hollow caues hath long bin hid,
Either fast closed in some hollow greaue,
That vnder it hidde hate and hollow guyle.
With hollow eyes and rawbone cheekes forspent,
His cheeke bones raw, and eie-pits hollow grew,
The cry whereof entring the hollow caue,
Vpon the earth, with hollow eyes deepe pent,
Vpon the ground, like to an hollow beare;
Farre in the forrest by a hollow glade,
And many feete fast thumping th'hollow ground,
Through hollow caues, that no man mote discouer
Nought there vnder heau'ns wilde hollownesse,
The caruer Holme, the Maple seeldom inward sound.
Was holpen vp, who him supported standing neare.
Helpe then, O holy Virgin chiefe of nine,
With holy father sits not with such things to mell.
There was an holy Chappell edifyde,
His holy things each morne and euentyde:
The holy Saints of their rich vestiments
Whiles none the holy things in safety kept;
Like to an holy Monck, the seruice to begin.
The sacred things, and holy heasts foretaught.
His reuerend haires and holy grauitie
And holy Martyrs often doen to dye,
Eftsoones vnto an holy Hospitall,
In holy righteousnesse, without rebuke or blame.
Wherein an aged holy man did lye,
Most trew, then said the holy aged man;
O holy Sire (quoth he) how shall I quight
Were hardned with that holy water dew,
Ere thou thy daughter linck in holy band
His owne two hands the holy knots did knit,
And holy water thereon sprinckled wide;
Who brought with him the holy grayle, (they say)
For the faire Damzell from the holy herse
And holy Church with faithlesse hands deface,
Distaines the pillours, and the holy grownd,
The second was an holy Nunne to chose,
An holy water Sprinckle, dipt in deowe,
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
Altars defyl'd, and holy things defast,
Weening therein some holy Hermit lay,
The holy fire, and all the embers strow
About their holy things for morrow Mas:
For by the holy vow, which me doth bind,
High Gods beheast, and powre of holy lawes;
Was wont his howres and holy things to bed;
His bloudy vessels wash, and holy fire prepare.
Regarding nought religion, nor their holy heast.
And running Heralds humble homage made,
To her I homage and my seruice owe,
And kisse my stirrup; that thy homage bee.
Such homage till that instant neuer learned hee.
And to her homage made, with humble grace:
Their sundry kings to do their homage seuerall.
And humble homage did vnto him make,
Those two strange knights such homage to her make,
Doth to his home entreate.
So with that godly father to his home they went.
And home she came, whereas her mother blynd
So marcheth home, and by her takes the knight,
Home is he brought, and laid in sumptuous bed:
Then home he suffred her for to retire,
To come vnto his wished home in haste,
That home ye may report thrise happie newes;
Abroad in armes, at home in studious kind
I home returning, fraught with fowle despight,
A straunger in thy home, and ignoraunt
For life ere long shall to her home retire,
But he it knew at home before he hard
Returned home, the royall Infant fell
With lighter hearts vnto their home retird;
He comming home at vndertime, there found
Her vp they tooke, and with them home her led,
So home he marcht emongst the horned heard,
And home returne, where all should be renewd
And comming home, in warlike fresh aray
Vnto her natiue home from mortall miserie.
Vnto her Coch remounting, home did ride,
Saw comming home; all voide of doubtfull feare,
That seem'd vnlike vnto his earthly home:
So home with her she streight the virgin lad,
And sent them home to tell a piteous tale,
But yet so fast they could not home retrate,
Come home to her in piteous wretchednesse,
And brought the pillage home, whence none could get it out.
Calidore brings Priscilla home,
With bleeding wounds, brought home vpon a Beare
Him oft desired home with her to wend,
And taking vp brought home, and noursed well
To helpe faire Pastorella, home to driue
Him to inuite vnto his simple home;
Being his harts owne wish, and home with him did go.
By which home came the fayrest Pastorell,
And leauing home, to roiall court I sought;
From natiue home, and spent my youth in vaine,
To call the soule backe to her home againe;
So home vnto his honest wife it bore,
And homebred euill ye desire to heare,
In homely wize, and wald with sods around,
Nor s'deignfull of so homely fashion,
Enur'd to hardnesse and to homely fare,
And shall see Stamford, though now homely hid,
And in his homely wize began to assay
Yet was their fare but homely, such as hee
Ere long to him a homely groome there came,
Such homely what, as serues the simple clowne,
And of his aged Beldame homely well;
Ne may this homely verse, of many meanest,
Yclad in home-made greene that her owne hands had dyde.
To heare the warlike feates, which Homere spake
Them reconcyld againe, and to their homes did driue.
That warn'd the shepheards to their homes to hast
Homeward to march, themselues there to repose,
And euery one gan homeward to resort.
So backe againe they homeward turnd their feete.
Gathered together, and them homeward bare:
Which long time had bene shut, and out of hond
Withhold, O soueraine Prince, your hasty hond
That shall I shortly purchase to your hond:
Had kindled: that she gaue into his hond,
Him needed not long call, she soone to hond
His Lords owne flesh. Therewith out of his hond
And said, Caytiue, cursse on thy cruell hond,
When as againe he armed felt his hond;
Then backe againe turning his busie hond,
Oppressours powre by armes and puissant hond?
As it deliuered was from hond to hond:
As it deliuered was from hond to hond:
Who taking it out of her tender hond,
To loose long gotten honour with one euill hond.
Through heauy stroke of Britomartis hond.
From dread of her reuenging fathers hond:
The rest he leaues in ground: so takes in hond
Then laid the noble Championesse strong hond
By that the louely paire drew nigh to hond:
So dreadfull were his strokes, so deadly was his hond.
Of that same wicked Carle, by Virgins hond;
For well she wist now in a mighty hond,
That keepes a Bridges passage by strong hond,
Which long agoe he taken had in hond:
That she to hunt the beast first tooke in hond;
Her honest merth and pleasaunce to partake;
And treading vnder foote her honest name:
Or ply him selfe to any honest trade,
And his faire wife, whom honest long he kept vneath.
Ne euer Lady of so honest name,
There he was welcom'd of that honest syre,
So home vnto his honest wife it bore,
And loued simple truth and stedfast honesty.
Two iron coffers hong on either side,
Vpon his brothers shield, which hong thereby:
Did him appease; then downe his taile he hong
There thirstie Tantalus hong by the chin;
He snatcht the vele, that hong her face before;
Thereby his mortall blade full comely hong
Which hong adowne his side in twisted gold,
Hong downe, and filthy matter from them weld;
Disordred hong about his shoulders round,
A multitude of babes about her hong,
And high emongst all knights hast hong thy shield,
But hong still on the shield, as it at first was pight.
His credit now in doubtfull ballaunce hong;
Grew all afore, and loosely hong vnrold,
By the hoare lockes, that hong before her eyes,
And hong their conquered armes for more defame
Or where hath he hong vp his mortall blade,
From whose rough vaut the ragged breaches hong,
And ouer it a faire Portcullis hong,
Till wearie of that wretched life, her selfe she hong.
And all that while, right ouer him she hong,
Of sleeping praise, were hong vpon a tree,
Both speare she tooke, and shield, which hong by it:
She hauing hong vpon a bough on high
Now loose about her shoulders hong vndight,
Vpon his lips hong faire Dame Hellenore,
